TALK.START.PARA: —I might give a little background. The government amendment sought to overcome a problem arising from the leasing method of calculating the appropriate amount in terms of the gross rental. The government amendment has actually been superseded as a result of a decision of the High Court not to allow special leave to appeal by Citicorp from a full Federal Court decision. The issue in that case was essentially that Citibank was assessable on the gross rentals received under the financed lease of cars but was entitled to a depreciation of limits, subject to the limitations contained in section 57AF of the cost limits. As a result of the decision of the Federal Court, reinforced by the decision of the High Court not to allow special leave to appeal to the High Court, the government's amendment is rendered unnecessary.
—We are continuing to propose the amendment. I thank Senator Watson for his assistance.

—These proposals were in the original bill. Since the drafting of the original bill, the High Court action was finalised and, as a result of that, the government does not intend to proceed with its amendment and has put a further amendment to the original bill to render clauses 24 and 25 unnecessary.

PARA.TAB: Clauses negatived.
Clauses 26 to 40—by leave—taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a proposed amendment to clause 40. I want to say something about this amendment which has been distributed for a couple of days now. I hope that honourable senators have had a chance to focus on this amendment. In effect, the amendment was accompanied by an explanatory note which details why I feel the amendment is necessary. It is a technical amendment designed to correct an erroneous view of the law which is being put forward by the Commissioner of Taxation in draft taxation ruling TR94/D8 on child maintenance trusts. The commissioner has adopted an extremely narrow technical interpretation of the phrase `pursuant to' which would prevent any person in the country from ever enjoying the benefit of the exemption which parliament gave to the children's income from child maintenance trusts.

PARA.TAB: It should be borne in mind that parliament made this decision and the effect of the proposed taxation ruling would be to deny the exemption in a way that was not intended by parliament. The purpose of the exemption was to prevent children's incomes from maintenance trusts being taxed at penalty rates.

The government itself has acknowledged the absurdity of the situation in a press release on the matter. However, according to the press release, the government does not propose that the law be amended to give effect to the original intention of parliament in relation to child maintenance trusts established before 7 March 1994. This amendment should not cause people too many problems. It is, after all, an attempt to restore what parliament intended.

One issue I want to raise with the committee is the way in which the commissioner has used the ruling system to attempt to impose upon taxpayers a blatantly artificial and contrived interpretation of the law which deprives them of that exemption which parliament clearly intended to give them. If the ruling system is to be used in that way—that is, to impose upon taxpayers views of the law which are not soundly based—parliament may have to consider the question of whether taxpayers should be subjected to any detriment where they choose, on better advice, to prepare their tax returns in a manner at variance with what is, after all, only the commissioner's view of the law.

Another issue is the tax treatment of family income transfers generally, but that is not a subject matter with which the committee needs to be involved at this stage. I do flag that at some stage I will be raising that matter. I again say that this is an effort to overcome the effect of a ruling by the Commissioner of Taxation which was to deny what parliament clearly intended to occur.

I reiterate that the commissioner's ruling is merely his view of the law. His extraordinarily narrow view of the phrase `pursuant to' may well be corrected by a court taking a purposive interpretation as in the Cooper Brooks case. However, it would be a waste of administrative and judicial resources to test by way of a set of legal disputes a futile interpretation of a law which no-one argues was the parliament's purpose. It would also wreak havoc amongst taxpayers. Parliament can correct this manifest error in administration and ensure that the intention of the law is fully carried out in regard to all child maintenance trusts established since the introduction of the original legislation. That is the purpose of my amendment.

I believe I have gone no further than restore what I believe to have been the intention of the parliament, which was superseded by the Taxation Commissioner's ruling. I have not actually moved the amendment at this stage. I will do so, however, depending on any response that the parliamentary secretary might give to my explanation in foreshadowing that amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The draft taxation ruling that Senator Harradine was referring to was TR94/D8 concerning child maintenance trusts. It has been suggested in relation to the draft ruling that perhaps the law may need some amendment. Adding to clause 40 is the basis for Senator Harradine's proposed amendment. My understanding of what he is seeking to achieve is that the underlying intention of division 6AA, which was always quite clear, could really be achieved. I believe that the announcement by the Treasurer was designed to make the necessary amendments. Perhaps he is seeking some sort of an assurance from the government. What stage are we at in relation to the issues raised by him? I think proceeding with his particular amendment is worthy of some assurance or comment.

—One of the problems with the press release of the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) is that it clearly is not the intention of the government to restore the benefit in respect of child maintenance trusts established before 7 March 1994. In other words, the Assistant Treasurer said that the Taxation Commissioner's ruling was really a nonsense—it was not in accordance with the intention of the parliament—but that the government would not do anything to restore the exemption from penalty tax on those child maintenance trusts which were established prior to his press release. What has his press release got to do with this?

PARA.TAB: I understand that very often taxation matters are dealt with by the Treasurer from the date of a press release. We have been down that road for many years. We have dealt with that subject in debate on retrospective tax measures that have come before this parliament over a number of years. This is not a question of retrospective tax measures. This is restoring to taxpayers their rights in accordance with the intention of the parliament. For the government to say now, by way of press release, that it is going to levy penalty rates of tax against child maintenance trusts which were established prior to the Assistant Treasurer's press release is a denial of justice. It is certainly a denial of the intention of this parliament when it made that decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The very authoritative Butterworths Weekly Tax Bulletin No.10/1994 states:

PARA.TAB: When Div 6AA was introduced, certain categories of income derived by minors were to continue to be taxed at ordinary rates. One such category was described in explanatory memorandum to Income Tax Assessment Bill (No. 6) 1979 as:
"Income from property transferred to a minor pursuant to court-ordered settlements arising as a result of divorce or judicial separation."
This exclusion was also stated to apply to income derived through a trust.

However, it appears that s 102AG(2)(c)(viii) was drafted incorrectly and on its face the ATO adopts the position in this draft ruling that the section cannot be given any operation or effect. This is because child maintenance orders are not made as part of or "pursuant to" divorce proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the Family Law Act 1975, maintenance is dealt with as a separate matter to divorce.

PARA.TAB: If the section cannot be interpreted to give it any sort of effect, it must clearly be amended to ensure that its underlying intention can be achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek an appropriate response from the tax office through the parliamentary secretary.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we get a response to the matter raised by Senator Watson, I indicate that I will be covering it to a significant extent in the comments I make in response to Senator Harradine's amendment. Firstly, the government will not accept Senator Harradine's amendment for two major reasons. One is that it does not believe that the detail of Senator Harradine's amendment is sufficient to cover the issue he is trying to address. We do not believe it is correctly worded or sufficient in its coverage.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, we are concerned about the retrospective element. Senator Harradine has been critical of the fact that the Assistant Treasurer's press release, in announcing that this matter does need to be dealt with, is prospective. That is a little harsh in that the tax treatment of trusts established before the date of the Assistant Treasurer's media release will be appropriate. They are not disadvantaged if they have been established before the date of the press release.

The government, as Senator Harradine has pointed out, has announced that normal rates of tax are to apply to arms-length rates of income for property transferred for the benefit of a child as part of a legal settlement following a family breakdown. This change is meant to apply to a range of such transfers of property which are not conditional on orders for dissolution or nullity of a marriage.

Senator Harradine's proposed amendment may not protect the position of all children for whose benefit property was transferred before the date of the effect of the government announcement. It may apply only to income from property transferred to provide for child maintenance. The most common situations in which property is transferred for a child's benefit in circumstances of family breakdown may not be dealt with by Senator Harradine's proposed amendment—for example, where parents cannot agree on the division of property between themselves but, nevertheless, agree to transfer some property for the benefit of their children.

The question of the date of the application of the changes that the government announced in that press release is something the government is prepared to consider when the bill is introduced for these changes and is put before the parliament some time between now and the end of this year. We are prepared to look at that operative day. At that time it will be necessary to consider the commissioner's view on the operation of the law as it stood before the announcement. At this stage, the commissioner has only issued a draft taxation ruling on which comment has been invited. Finally, it would also be necessary to consider the date of application of other changes announced by the government as part of that legislative package. I am not sure whether that answers Senator Watson's question fully. That is the government's position in response to Senator Harradine's proposed amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened carefully to what the parliamentary secretary has said. In those circumstances, and given those undertakings, I will not be proceeding with my amendment.

—What will be the status of those trusts created prior to Mr Gear's announcement, given that that was only a draft ruling and it is the government's intention to change prospectively rather than retrospectively?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is, in effect, a prospective date from the date of the Assistant Treasurer's announcement, then trusts created before that date of the Treasurer's announcement, whatever it was, would obtain the benefits from the date of the announcement. If the legislation is retrospective—
—But you are not going to make it retrospective.

—We may consider that. In respect of Senator Harradine's matter, the government will consider retrospectivity, but we cannot give any undertakings on that at this point in time. TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY

—What is the status of a draft ruling by the Taxation Office when it comes to the assessment of child maintenance trusts? But there is the aspect of denial to those child maintenance trusts of their entitlement to be taxed at ordinary rates rather than at penalty rates.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The ruling that has been referred to in this debate is a considered view, but it is not a view that either auditors or taxpayers should accept and be bound by in this period when there is some uncertainty. Certainly it is the government's hope that the package of measures to overcome the problem that has arisen will be implemented as quickly as we can get it into a reasonable form.

Clauses 41 to 47—by leave—taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have concerns about the bunching effect. The group test, in terms of the company tax instalment rules, differs from the group test applicable to the transfer of losses and other taxation matters. Can the government explain why a uniform group test in the Income Tax Assessment Act is not the simplest and most efficient method? I remind the chamber that large companies will now be required to lodge their tax returns on 1 December instead of on 15 March. TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

I draw the committee's attention to that because it will have a severe impact on cash flow financing arrangements; but the group test differs somewhat under these purposes compared with the general test.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek to proceed first with amendments nos 1, 2, 3 and 4 to clause 53 for the reason that I outlined in my second reading speech. I shall briefly reiterate those reasons.

PARA.TAB: By amending clause 53 we are seeking to remove the cap, the limit which is placed on the rebate scheme by government. We find it rather strange that a rebate would be made available but that the total amount in that rebate would be limited and people would have to apply to get a rebate. It is quite unlike most other rebates, tax deductions or anything else that apply in this area of law.

If those series of amendments are not accepted, then we do not intend to proceed with the amendments to the other clauses, including clause 52, which would extend the application of the rebate scheme from the built heritage to the natural environment. As I explained, the reasons for that are that, if the amount is to be limited, we certainly do not want to limit the availability of the rebate scheme in the built heritage even further by extending it to the natural environment, even though the Heritage Commission and other bodies are in favour of such an extension but in favour of an extension under an expanded scheme. So I seek leave to proceed with the amendments to clause 53 first before dealing with clause 52.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to clause 53, the opposition has a number of amendments which it would also like to move. Perhaps it may have been desirable to attend to clause 52 and then to proceed to clause 53.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Herron)—One way around it would be possibly to take clauses 52 and 53 together.
Clauses 52 and 53—by leave—taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 53, page 21, proposed section 159UA, omit paragraph B3. of the simplified outline.
2.Clause 53, page 22, proposed section 159UB, line 8, omit definition of "maximum approval limit".
3.Clause 53, page 22, lines 24 to 32, omit proposed section 159UD.
4.Clause 53, page 23, proposed paragraph 159UF(1)(b), lines 11 and 12, omit "and that the total specified in respect of a financial year does not exceed the maximum approval limit for the year".
I should explain that amendments nos 5, 6, 7 and so on are consequential upon the above amendments and relate to the extension of the application of the rebate scheme to natural areas.

PARA.TAB: I think everybody in the chamber would know that under the tax law there is a rebate scheme in relation to medical expenses in excess of $1,000. The government in no sense seeks to put a cap on that amount; a person is either entitled to a rebate or is not. We find it rather strange that in this area the government may well be breaking totally new ground in providing a rebate but giving power to the minister to limit the total amount of that rebate scheme, and then setting up an elaborate structure by which people would have to reapply for the application of the rebate to their particular work. Clause B3 of section 159UA says:

SPEECH.PARA: The total of the amounts specified in certificates that the Minister approves in a financial year is not to exceed a limit set by the Minister (section 159UD). As a result, not all applications that may otherwise have been approved will be able to be approved, and some taxpayers may get approval for only part of the expenditure that they will incur.

We find that rather strange in tax law. Therefore, we would seek to remove that limit. If it is appropriate for the government to provide rebates in the area of the built heritage, it is appropriate for that rebate scheme to be unlimited.

PARA.TAB: Further, we are saying that if that limit is removed—if that amendment should be passed—there are significant areas in the natural heritage also that should be able to benefit from the extension of the rebate scheme, and that is covered by amendments Nos 5 to 10. As I have indicated, I do not want to proceed with the other amendments if the cap remains in place. I certainly encourage honourable senators to support the removal of that cap.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition naturally has sympathy with the issues raised by the Australian Democrats. We do not find it at all surprising that the Democrats have raised these issues. Certainly the National Trust, while grateful for the innovation that has been introduced here, feels that perhaps $2 million is far too low and that a figure tenfold that is more appropriate. Senator Coulter has suggested that even that figure may be also inadequate and has asked the Senate, in effect, for a blank cheque. Senator Coulter has not put before the Senate the likely cost consequences of the Democrat's proposal. Given the impact on revenue, we would have some concern about the open-ended nature of the effect of the amendment. For that reason, the opposition will not be supporting it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not be supporting the amendments of Senator Coulter. As Senator Watson has pointed out, it would be an open-ended cost. The government is implementing a program that has been welcomed by everyone. Unfortunately, some people are saying, `It is not enough. It should be open-ended. Not even $2 million a year is sufficient'. Senator Coulter's proposals are difficult to cost, as Senator Watson has pointed out, but they would cost maybe $10 million or $20 million a year.

PARA.TAB: I am a lover of all buildings. I recall my old family home in Richmond, Tasmania. It is a very old town which contains the oldest Catholic church, the oldest bridge, and the second oldest Anglican church in Australia, and a range of very old historic buildings. I used to live in one of them. During my youth my parents spent quite a lot of time and money doing up that old building. Later on when my parents moved to the north-west coast of Tasmania to the small township of Latrobe they had what would be regarded as an historic cottage and they spent some money and effort doing it up. I have been doing up an old terrace house, which is over 100 years old, in my new residence in Burnie. It was moved to there from a mining community on the west coast. I do enjoy and have a great love for our heritage, but there are limits to the extent to which we can fund these sorts of initiatives.

I do not accept Senator Coulter's analogy of no limits on rebates in the health area. Certain cost areas that affect our lives should not have a cap on the rebate, and medical costs are one. It is not possible to say to a person facing a leg operation, `You can have half the operation', whereas, when renovating a building, it is quite possible to say, `You can renovate a part of the building but you cannot renovate the whole of the building'. The former example would be a calamity for the patient; the latter would not be a calamity for the building.

Then there is Senator Coulter's comparison of the total costs. The government has a variety of measures to keep the lid on total medical costs—I will not go into them here—so it is not correct to say that there is no cap on expenditure in those areas. For those reasons, and for the reasons advanced by Senator Watson, we cannot accept the removal of the cap. I note that if the cap is not removed—it is apparent that that will not happen—Senator Coulter does not intend to press his other amendments which go to the inclusion of natural areas of significance, so I do not intend to go into detail on those matters today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am disappointed with the government's response to this matter. Our estimate, which is in the budget proposals we put to government, is that the amount might be some $10 million rather than the $2 million mentioned—although I have to agree with the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) that it is rather hard to estimate those things accurately.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the other amendments which I have announced that I will not be proceeding with, I wonder whether the parliamentary secretary would give an assurance—given the fact that the National Trust, the Heritage Commission and other bodies associated with this would like to see this cap removed or certainly extended, and would also like to see natural areas included—that these matters would be given consideration over the coming year or so. Could he also assure us that when we deal with another amending bill, which we will do in the next year or so, we might look forward to some improvement along the lines of the amendments that I have suggested?
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McGauran)—For clarification, Senator Coulter, we will take it that you do not wish to move any more amendments at all and that you are withdrawing all amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. I will be moving other amendments which are standing in the name of Senator Kernot.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Coulter's comments, I cannot give him any undertaking. Frankly, I was not aware that costings had been included in the approach taken in the Australian Democrats' budget proposals which have been given to the government, but that would be pursued in the normal course of negotiations with the government. Beyond that, I cannot give any undertaking.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Clause 53, page 21, proposed section 159UA, paragraph A1. of the simplified outline, omit "$10,000", substitute "$5,000".
3.Clause 53, page 21, proposed section 159UA, paragraph C2. of the simplified outline, omit "$10,000", substitute "$5,000".
4.Clause 53, page 23, proposed paragraph 159UF(1)(b), line 11, omit "$10,000", substitute "$5,000".
5.Clause 53, page 25, proposed paragraph 159UM(1)(b), line 21, omit "$10,000", substitute "$5,000".

I remind the Senate that clause 53, to which the amendments relate, inserts a new sub-division in income tax law, sub-division AAD—heritage and conservation rebate. The sub-division provides for rebates of tax for approved expenditure on certain conservation work on listed heritage buildings and structures, and expenditure must be at least $10,000.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the series of amendments that we have introduced is to reduce that minimum from $10,000 to $5,000 because we are concerned that there will be a lot of people who will spend amounts of money under $10,000 and who could be denied this sort of benefit. I am also concerned about the inclusion of these sorts of provisions in income tax legislation. In the interests of equity and fairness, I would have preferred these to be in the form of grants rather than rebates because lower income earners in our community who may live in old cottages will not necessarily get any financial benefit as a result of the measures that we will be passing today. Therefore, in terms of equity and fairness it would be more appropriate that pensioners and low income earners, who may not have a taxable income but necessarily have to spend money on upgrading their old cottages and buildings, should be entitled to something.

We have seen cases before where the benefits tended to be given to the more affluent members of our community, and for this reason I have some hesitancy in using the Income Tax Assessment Act for this particular purpose. The amendments provide a 20 per cent rebate for approved expenditure on buildings listed on Commonwealth and state or territory heritage lists. At a time when the government is actually preaching tax simplification I ask the parliamentary secretary why these measures are included in a tax bill, especially when expenditure need not be related in any way to income producing activities of the taxpayer. I will leave it there and at a later date proceed with a further amendment in relation to clause 53, because it covers another issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —On that point, I understand that Senator Watson may not be proceeding with one of the amendments, depending on the details that the government gives him.
—No, I am coming to that later.

—The Democrats will be supporting these opposition amendments very much for the reason that Senator Watson has just outlined. I share his views about equity and fairness and the inclusion of this in tax legislation rather than by way of some sort of grant. Certainly, there would be many people living in older heritage buildings where annual expenditure would be considerably less than even $5,000, and yet that work would be absolutely essential for the proper maintenance of the building, particularly if people were doing the work themselves and the cost was really a cost of materials. We support this reduction on the grounds of equity and fairness and we think it adds to the likelihood that heritage buildings will be better cared for.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two matters here. Firstly, Senator Watson has dealt with the proposal that there should be a grant, and also with the proposal to lower the minimum threshold from $10,000 to $5,000. I can detect when I am out-voted on a matter and fairly obviously the amendments on the minimum sum will be passed. I make a point about lowering the threshold for conservation work to $5,000: the government has targeted work over $10,000 because it is balancing the overall goal of conserving a significant number of historic properties against the administrative costs of spreading the conservation dollar further. As we have a limit of $2 million there would be—
—But you are spreading it to the wrong people.

—With due respect, Senator Watson, we do not know. Frankly, from my experience I do not think $10,000 would go that far, given some of the costs involved in buildings. At the recent heritage ministers' conference, the state and territory ministers, including the Liberal ministers, agreed to cooperate in managing a new Commonwealth tax scheme which promotes the conservation of heritage buildings and structures. However, the ministers were anxious to ensure that the scheme was manageable. It is important to monitor approved work to ensure the scheme does not encourage damaging or inappropriate work. The greater number of smaller projects will be difficult to oversee. Owners of commercial properties can already claim for maintenance work under other sections of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.

PARA.TAB: Although the proposal would add substantially to administrative costs and place an extra burden on the Commonwealth, states and territories who are partners in this scheme, the government certainly was willing to review the threshold of $10,000 after the program had been running for one year or more. That has not been taken up by the Senate, and it is apparent that it will not be. We regret that it has not been.

On the other matter of the grants scheme, the government in its scheme is responding to more than a decade of lobbying from state and territory governments and organisations such as the National Trust, the Building Owners and Managers Association of Australia and the International Council of Monuments and Sites. For every $1 million in revenue forgone by the government $5 million is spent on heritage conservation work. It is very labour-intensive and has a very useful spin-off of being a significant contributor to employment. The government believes that the approach we have adopted in terms of administrative costs and ensuring that the work is done in a correct and accurate manner, is a preferable approach to a simple grants scheme where the controls and criteria might not be able to be applied as tightly as we would like.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 6.Clause 53, page 22, at the end of proposed section 159UB, add the following subsection:
"(2) For the purposes of the meaning of heritage conservation works, the National Trust Classified Lists are, until 30 June 1995, deemed to be a recognised heritage register.".

In speaking to the amendment, I indicate that the opposition has been pressed very strongly by representatives of the National Trust of Australia for the inclusion of such an amendment. There is a limitation until 30 June, so we believe there is a necessary incentive to encourage the quick listing of heritage conservation works that are not on a state or Commonwealth register. However, from speaking to representatives of the government agencies, I understand that they are prepared to give this parliament a commitment. I now seek that commitment and, if we believe that is adequate, I may consider withdrawing the amendment that I have just moved.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to the statement I made this morning, Senator Watson asked for some additions—
—Speaking to the amendment, in terms of the commitment that you indicated earlier in your second reading speech and the additional amount that was discussed during the lunch break.

—I have a new commitment from the minister following on from the statement I read before the lunch break. I will read it and then it is obviously up to Senator Watson as to whether he believes it reflects the discussions he has had. On behalf of Minister Lee, I can confirm that the Australian Heritage Commission, for a limited time only, is willing to ensure that in states and territories where there are not yet substantial state heritage registers, it will undertake priority assessments of those places which are only on National Trust registers and have applied for the scheme. These accelerated assessments of places for inclusion on the register of the national estate will ensure that owners in states where there are no or limited state registers are in no way disadvantaged. This is in keeping with the program of national coordination which the states and territories are undertaking with the Commonwealth, and it would be welcomed by them. The program includes consolidation of heritage lists.

—I seek a further assurance in terms of what `for a limited time' means. The coalition specified in our amendment `until 30 June'. What does the heritage agency consider to be an appropriate and reasonable time? After speaking with a number of state authorities, I think they perhaps would be in agreement with the undertaking that Senator Sherry has just given, provided that the reasonable time interval can be specified a bit more clearly.
—The time limit that Senator Watson refers to would be 30 June next year, which I understand would be acceptable.

—That being so, and given the attitude of ministers from a number of territories and states, we will accept the undertaking because it is very much in line with the intent and purpose of the amendment that we have just put, and which I now seek to withdraw. I thank the parliamentary secretary and his advisers for the consideration that has been given to the matter, because I believe there is now a very good incentive to work in close collaboration with the National Trust to ensure that the state and other registers are up-to-date. I thank Senator Sherry for that assurance.

—I raise a question on this matter. Senator Watson's amendment, if proceeded with, would have had the effect that during the coming financial year applicants for rebates on buildings which fell within the National Trust classified lists but outside the other heritage lists would be eligible, but the removal of his amendment and the substitution of the government's assurance mean that in the coming financial year none of those applicants will have that rebate scheme available to them. They will have to wait until post-June or July 1995. That is the effect of it, as I understand it.
—I tend to disagree because if there can be close coordination to get these items on, from the time they are on the appropriate register they will be entitled to the rebate.
—I would agree with Senator Watson. I do not agree with Senator Coulter. I do believe Senator Watson has explained the situation as we understand it and that is what we have agreed on.

—So that we get this absolutely straight, in other words, there is essentially a running list of registered heritage buildings which will be continually updated and that will be completed by June 1995 so that there will be a minimum difference in the coming financial year between those that are now on the list and those that will come on the list and therefore are at least potentially eligible.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter is right, except it is only those that request to go on the list. The organisations request to go on the list themselves. I do not think that is controversial.

PARA.TAB: Amendment—by leave—withdrawn.

"56L.After section 79C of the Principal Act the following section is inserted:
